articles.title: The State of JavaScript 2024 Results
articles.description: We recently encouraged you to take the annual State of JavaScript survey; the results are now out. 14,015 folks took part and we get to see what language features folks are using, experiences with popular libraries, build tool popularity, AI preferences, popular podcasts, runtime usage, and perhaps controversially, how more JavaScript developers are using TypeScript than not. There‚Äôs a lot to dig through here.
articles.author: Sacha Greif

articles.title: 1.¬†console.delight
articles.description: By far our most popular link of the year with over 20,000 clicks(!) ‚Äì but who doesn't use and love console.log? This post showed us how in the browser console it's not merely for printing plain text, but can be used to render things like SVGs and HTML.
articles.author: Zach Saucier

articles.title: 2.¬†JavaScript Visualized: Promise Execution
articles.description: A well-diagrammed article coupled with an (optional) 8 minute video that went into how promises work under the hood. Hugely popular as most of Lydia's content tends to be.
articles.author: Lydia Hallie

articles.title: 3.¬†Is htmx Just Another JavaScript Framework?
articles.description: Despite being five years old, htmx has seen a surge in popularity in 2023 and 2024, partly due to framework fatigue, but also as its simple HTML-oriented approach to adding functionality to pages appeals to a diverse group of developers. v2.0 landed in June.
articles.author: Alexander Petros

articles.title: 4.¬†Ecma International Approves ECMAScript 2024: What‚Äôs New?
articles.description: In June, the Ecma General Assembly approved the latest ECMAScript / JavaScript spec, officially making it a standard. As with ES2023, it was a reasonably small step forward, but Dr. Axel rounded up what was new.
articles.author: Dr. Axel Rauschmayer

articles.title: 5.¬†JavaScript's ??= Operator: Default Values Made Simple
articles.description: The ??= nullish coalescing assignment operator snuck into JavaScript a few years ago via ES2021 and has been broadly supported almost everywhere for ages. Trevor showed off how it can tighten up your assignments.
articles.author: Trevor I. Lasn

articles.title: 6.¬†Eloquent JavaScript: The Fourth Edition
articles.description: Coming several years after the third edition, the latest version of what is, perhaps, the best ‚Äòall rounder‚Äô book for learning JavaScript arrived in March ‚Äúadjusted to the realities of 2024 and generally touched up.‚Äù
articles.author: Marijn Haverbeke

articles.title: 7.¬†33 JavaScript Concepts Every Developer Should Know
articles.description: A curated collection of links to tutorials on 33 different areas it‚Äôs worth understanding well, including types, closures, equality, scope, and different engines.
articles.author: Leonardo Maldonado

articles.title: 8.¬†How Google Handles JavaScript In Its Indexing Process
articles.description: At one point if you wanted Google to index your content it needed to be directly written in HTML and not dynamically rendered with JavaScript. Things have since changed, of course, but by how much?
articles.author: Zecchini, Moore, Siddle, Ubl (Vercel)

articles.description: ü•á JetBrains' recent State of Developer Ecosystem report shows that JavaScript is "the most used programming language", reports InfoWorld's Paul Krill. The report also claims "despite its gains, TypeScript will not replace JavaScript".
üóìÔ∏è We've just finished 2024 wrap ups in the latest issue of Node Weekly and React Status, if you want more depth into those topics.
ü§ñ GitHub has made its Copilot AI assistant available for free (with limits). We also learn that there are now 150 million developers on GitHub.
üáµüá± If you're in Poland, consider heading along to the next WarsawJS meetup on January 8. Esteemed Polish computer scientist Andrzej Blikle will be speaking, amongst others.
ü§ñ Vercel is running a State of AI developer survey they'd like you to take.
JerryScript 3.0 ‚Äì 'Ultra lightweight' JS engine for IoT/embedded use cases with full ES 5.1 compliance and 84% Test262 conformance.
ü§ñ Transformers.js v3.2 ‚Äì Run machine learning models in the browser. Now supporting Moonshine real-time speech recognition and Phi 3.5 Vision.
Bun 1.1.39 and 1.1.40 ‚Äì The fast JS runtime gets a human-readble lockfile format, fetch bodies can now be streams, and Node compatibility improves.
Prisma 6.1 ‚Äì Popular ORM for Node.js and TypeScript. Tracing is now GA.
pnpm 10.0 RC 0, ESLint v9.17.0, Recharts 2.15

articles.title: Balancing Text in CSS
articles.description: Ahmad kicks off the new year with this great interactive article explaining how we can make text more visually balanced using CSS. It‚Äôs a solid run through of what text-wrap and its different values can do.
articles.author: Ahmad Shadeed

articles.title: New Frontend Features for Designers in 2025
articles.description: Cosima notes that when searching for frontend workflows and toolkits, it‚Äôs easy to forget how powerful some of the fundamentals on the web have become. As such, this post is a journey through new features and what they are capable of.
articles.author: Cosima Mielke

articles.title: (Relatively) New Things You Should Know about HTML Heading Into 2025
articles.description: Chris Coyier takes a look at some of the more modern features of HTML worth knowing about. Luckily they‚Äôre not all cutting edge, but things you can actually use right now.
articles.author: Chris Coyier

articles.title: The Future of Htmx
articles.description: htmx is the new jQuery? Well, it‚Äôs an ideal that the htmx team are actually striving for, looking to emulate the ‚Äútechnical characteristics of jQuery that make it such a low-cost, high-value addition to the toolkits of web developers‚Äù.
articles.author: Gross & Petros

articles.title: Principles of Web Accessibility: How to Approach Accessible Web Interface Design
articles.description: A dozen, snappy high-level guiding principles for approaching web accessibility.
articles.author: Heydon Pickering

articles.title: 'HTML Is Actually a Programming Language. Fight Me'
articles.description: ‚ÄúHTML‚Äôs promise is that we can build, make, code, and do anything we want.‚Äù
articles.author: Tim Carmody

articles.title: CSS Wants to Be a 'System'
articles.description: ‚ÄúAt the core of CSS is a series of cascading rules and classes marrying and mingling in an elegant symphony of style application.‚Äù
articles.author: Dave Rupert

articles.title: üóìÔ∏è¬†CSS Selectors Knowledge
articles.description: We shared a bunch of dev focused ‚Äòadvent calendars‚Äô last month, but here‚Äôs one that we missed ‚Äî of course the benefit of sharing now means all the doors are open üòâ. This resource shares various CSS selectors along with a quick video explainer and quiz to help build out your knowledge.
articles.author: Frontendly

articles.title: ‚ñ∂¬†¬†Reckoning: Frontend's Lost Decade
articles.description: In this roughly hour long talk Alex discusses platforms, apps, and the mobile web and why it‚Äôs important for us to get frontend culture ‚Äúrefocused on users, rather than ‚ÄòDX‚Äô snake oil‚Äù.
articles.author: Alex Russell

articles.title: Publishing a Simple Client-Side JS Package to npm with GitHub¬†Actions
articles.description: As part of the process of building Prompts.js, a new library for creating simple await-able alternatives to alert(), confirm() and prompt(), Simon wanted to make it easy to publish as an npm package too.
articles.author: Simon Willison

articles.title: Knowing CSS is Mastery to Frontend Development
articles.description: Frameworks come and go, so Anselm reminds us that understanding the underlying mechanisms of a language is the key to really mastering it.
articles.author: Anselm Hannemann

articles.title: CSS Variables Editor: A Chrome Extension for Managing Colors in CSS Variables
articles.description: Works with any site that uses CSS variables, but is designed to work well with shadcn/ui or daisyUI. You can also use it to check color contrast accessibility scores and generate palettes via AI.
articles.author: James Chetwood

articles.title: Flexoki ‚Äî An Open-Source Color Scheme for Prose & Code
articles.description: If you‚Äôre looking for a nice color palette to reach for beyond the Tailwind CSS usuals, this here is a solid option. Lots of nice inky colours, inspired by ink/paint pigments on paper. There‚Äôs a good explainer here too on the decisions made. Repo here.
articles.author: Steph Ango

articles.title: Type Scale Generator: Interactive Type Scale Editor & Code Generator
articles.description: Provides a live preview of the settings you choose and you can export the code as CSS, SCSS, Tailwind, or even JSON for use in WordPress.
articles.author: Landin.gs

articles.title: Tipex: An Advanced Rich Text Editor for Svelte
articles.description: Based on the popular Tiptap editor framework, it‚Äôs customizable, has theming support, and is Svelte 5-ready. Here‚Äôs a live example.
articles.author: Friend of Svelte

articles.title: Easing Graphs: A Gallery of Easing Graphs for CSS and Framer¬†Motion
articles.description: You can select any of the graphs to interactively customize the easing code as needed, and you can filter by the style of easing (in, out, in-out). Code can be copied as cubic-bezier-based CSS or Framer Motion component.
articles.author: Alex Vanderzon & Lochie Axon

articles.title: jsontr.ee: A Library to Visualize JSON Structures as Dynamic SVG Tree Diagrams
articles.description: You can try it out on this playground, which provides the option to download the diagram as PNG, or use it in an app with customizable styles.
articles.author: Lou Alcal√°

articles.title: DOOM: The Gallery Experience
articles.description: A game developer has created this amusing version of DOOM, parodying art gallery openings, complete with curated pieces, wine, fancy music, and even hors d‚Äôoeuvres. If you fancy starting the new year with some culture then this is playable directly in the browser (which gives me an excuse to share it here...).
articles.author: boba
